The low-temperature behavior of CO oxidation was investigated using 0.1 mol Ce doped Co supported on alumina catalysts prepared using co-precipitation followed by deposition precipitation method. The impact of calcination temperature on CO oxidation with kinetic aspects has been studied in detail and correlated to the characterizations. The Ce doped CoAl catalyst calcined at optimum temperature (550 ⁰C) shoed formation of more facile Co3+, Ce3+, and adsorbed species. The Co, Ce, and alumina interaction leads to the formation of optimum penta and hexa coordinated alumina. The physicochemical properties of the catalyst have been studied in detail using XRD, FTIR, Raman, TPR, XPS, and 27Al NMR and correlated to the catalytic activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Calcination effect Higher CO oxidation Lattice oxygen Al-coordination etc 1 Introduction CO is affecting human health and biosystems by disturbing their respiratory and nitrogen fixation processes [1]. The emission of CO is emitted from many fields like automotive exhaust, mine rescue, many industrial power plants, and housing activities [2,3]. Abatement of CO from the environment released by many natural and anthropogenic sources is important to control problem of environmental pollution. Hence, the removal of CO by catalytic oxidation at ambient temperature is one of the prime processes to control pollution. There are a number of catalytic systems like precious metals (Pt, Pd, Rh, Ir, Au, and Ag) [4–6], metal oxides (CuO, MnO2, Co3O4, Al2O3, V2O5, Fe2O3, etc.), Transition metals (Ni, Fe, Mn, Cu, Cr, Zn, etc.), perovskite, spinel, hopcalite, etc. used for abatement of toxic exhaust gasses [7–14]. Among them, cobalt oxide showed significant CO oxidation activity achieved between 298 K to 488 K [15,16]. Transition metals are distinguished from other metals by variation in oxidation states. These metals have high dissociation probability and low adsorption energy, and are commonly utilized to trigger the surface catalysed processes like CO oxidation. It also can split molecular oxygen at low temperatures and bind strongly to both atomic oxygen and CO [11]. The catalytic properties are related to the association of metal and support. The support plays a crucial role in deciding the dispersion and reducibility of doped metal. Supports like Al2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 have been revealed to have better metal-support interaction and low reducibility. Catalyst treatment such as reduction and calcination temperatures indirectly affect the catalyst structural properties, metal-support interactions, crystal size, and oxidation states of metals [6]. Al2O3 is a widely used support material because of its high thermal stability and surface area [17]. In various high-temperature reactions, strong interaction between metal and support led to the formation of a large particle on the surface of support which is not an active phase. Hence, the preparation of material with metal particles smaller is responsible for the high dispersion of active metals on the support plays a crucial role to exhibit superior activity [18]. The mixed oxides of ceria-cobalt have been shown to enhance specific surface areas resulting in good CO oxidation performance [19–21]. The addition of promoters like ceria has been revealed to enhance the reducibility and dispersion. It is very well known that CeO2 exhibits excellent oxygen storage capacity and acts as a promoter in many catalytic oxidation reactions. The redox couple Ce4+/Ce3+ showed superior oxidation–reduction properties for high oxidation activity. The performance of CeO2 is enhanced by combination with transition metals in CO oxidation [22–24]. Hence, using a small amount of CeO2 as a promoter in cobalt alumina support improved the catalytic properties [21]. Based on the above consideration, CoCe0.1Al catalyst was prepared by coprecipitation followed by the deposition method which was highly active and moderate sulfur resistance briefly reported in our previous communication. The surface morphological characteristics of catalysts are greatly influenced by the temperature of calcination like surface properties, oxidation state, lattice defects, and ultimately catalyst performance [25]. The calcination temperature affects the dispersion of cobaltic active species, which reduced as the calcination temperature increases. Co3O4 and CeO2 are said to be important aspects of high-performance catalysts for CO oxidation and their particle size increases with calcination temperature [26,27]. However, the effect of calcination temperature on both structural and chemical characteristics and activity is needed to examine. The present study explores the influence of calcination temperature on catalytic efficiency and structural characteristics of Co/Cex-Al. The catalyst's morphological characteristics were investigated by XRD, FTIR, Raman, XPS, H2-TPR, and 27Al solid-state NMR, correlated to the CO oxidation. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation process Al(NO3)3·9H2O (98.0%, LOBA Chemie), Ce(NO3)2·4H2O (99.5% SDFCL), NH4OH (25% v/v, SDFCL), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99.0% SDFCL) were used without additional purification. Ce doped cobalt-alumina (CoOx/[Cex -Al 0.5]) series of catalysts were synthesized with a different molar ratio by coprecipitation followed by a deposition method. Ce doping was carried out on CoAl support ([Co0.5/(Ce0.1-Al0.4)] = 1 mol). Initially, a coprecipitation method was used to prepare the [(Ce0.1-Al0.4)] support. The determined amount of precursor Ce(NO3)2·4H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O were solubilized separately in 100 mL deionized (DI) water and formed a homogenous solution by dropwise addition with continuous stirring according to their respective molar ratios. This Co and Al nitrate mixture was precipitated with 10% NH4OH with drop-by-drop addition and continuous stirring at pH 10 for 24 h. Moreover, the precipitate was extensively washed and filtered with normal and hot DI water. This washed precipitate was kept for drying at 100 °C for 24 h in the oven. Furthermore, the dried precipitate was calcined at 500, 550, and 600 °C for 4 h. The resultant powder was denoted as Ce0.1Al-500, Ce0.1Al-550 and Ce0.1Al-600 respectively. Furthermore, the deposition of Co on CexAl was accomplished by dissolving Co(NO3)2·6H2O in 100 mL DI water. Above solution was introduced in the above prepared CexAl aqueous slurry. The mixture was precipitated with 10% NH4OH till pH 8 with constant stirring for 24 h. The precipitate formed was kept for drying at 120 °C and dried in an oven at 100 °C for 24 h. The dried material was calcined at different temperatures such as 500, 550 and 600 °C for 4 h and designated as CoCe0.1Al_500, CoCe0.1Al_550 and CoCe0.1Al_600 respectively. CoOx supported on alumina was synthesized by the deposition precipitation method in absence of Ce. This catalyst was denoted as CoAl. 2.2 Catalytic experiment The CO oxidation reaction of prepared catalysts were accomplished with the help of tubular downflow reactor (I.D. 15 mm) at atmospheric pressure and temperature from 30 to 400 °C (2 °C min−1 rate). 0.5 g of catalyst and 2.0 g of diluent silicon carbide mixture were taken in the reactor and temperature of reaction was monitored by a temperature sensor inserted on the catalyst bed. The flow of reaction mixture was controlled using mass flow controllers (MFC). Furthermore, the catalyst was preheated for activation at 400 °C for 1 h in 10% oxygen with helium balance with rate 5 °C.min−1 rate. After completion of activation, the reactor was brought down to room temperature and oxidation activity was carried out. The CO oxidation activity testing was studied at 20,000 mL.g−1.h−1 gas hourly space velocity (GHSV). The analysis of reaction outlet gasses was carried out by micro GC (490 model) by Agilent with MS 5A, PPQ and CP Sil 5CB column. The quantification of model components was calculated by using the equation given below. (1) % Conversion ( CO ) = CO ( Initial ) − CO ( Final ) CO ( Initial ) × 100 2.3 Characterization methods The powder XRD analysis was done with XRD-6100 by Shimadzu with a nickel filtered Cu Kα (= 1.54, 40 kV, 30 mA) source of radiation to manufacture catalysts. Diffraction patterns were recorded with a step size of 0.02° from 20 to 80°. The catalysts surface area studied using Smart Instruments Co.'s Smart Sorb 92/93 equipment. The calcined catalysts were heated initially for 120 min at 150 °C in N2 flow, followed by adsorption of N2 at −196 °C. The iCAP RQ ICP spectrometer was used to analyze the elemental composition in the prepared catalysts. The wavelength for the analysis was between 160 and 800 nm. Fourier- Transform transmission infrared (FTIR) were recorded by Perkin Elmer (Spectrum two) instrument fitted with ATR crystal Diamond. The spectra were recorded with the wavelength from 400 to 4000 cm−1 at RT with a resolution 0.5 cm−1. Raman analysis was carried out with the help of B & W Tek features with STRam-1064 laser (514.5 nm) Raman spectrometer from 3000 to 10 cm−1. Hydrogen- Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was employed to examine the redox behavior of manufactured catalysts using the Thermo Scientific Tritek equipment. The catalyst (100 mg) was placed by using U-shaped reactor (quartz) and heated for 1 hour at 450 °C in 10% O2. The catalyst was reduced with 5% H2 with Ar balancing at a 20 mL.min−1. The reducibility of all catalysts was measured from 40 to 800 °C with 5 °C min−1 rate. The KARATOS Analytical-AXIS supra equipment with monochromatic illumination A1 K alpha, was used to conduct the XPS analysis (10 mA, 15 kV). XPS spectra were taken in the region of 1200 to 0 eV with step size of 1 eV. The binding energy (B.E.) of the corresponding catalyst calibration was done using the C 1 s maxima at 284.6 eV. NMR SPECTROMETER (ECZR Series 600 MHz) with rapid MAS was used to investigate the structural analysis of Al (20KHz). 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of synthesized catalysts 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The sequence of XRD of CoCe0.1Al material was calcined at 500, 550, and 600 °C exhibited in Fig. 1 . The XRD spectra of Co0.1Al sample showed 2θ at 31.2, 36.9, 45.0, 59.5, and 65.4⁰ related to the characteristic features of spinel cobalt as a Co3O4 (JCPDS 00–042–1467) phase. The diffraction pattern of γ-Al2O3 phase were not observed at 36.4, 45.9, 66.46⁰ (JCPDS No. 29–006) and could be due to the poor degree of crystallinity of the catalyst. In CoCe0.1Al, a set of signals are observed at 2θ 28.3, 32.4, 47.4, 58.6, and 76.5⁰ are characteristic features of the cubic phase of CeO2 (JCPDS-34–0394) [21]. The CeO2 showed peak at 32.8⁰ which is shifted towards lower side due to interaction with cobalt. The peak was broadened with increase in temperature and could be due to lower crystallite size of Ce. The crystallite size order of Co3O4 calculated at 36.9⁰ is CoCe0.1Al_500 (13.9 nm) > CoAl (15.9 nm) > CoCe0.1Al_550 (17.8 nm) > CoCe0.1Al_600 (18.8 nm). The increase in temperature of calcination temperature from 500 to 600 °C leads to increase in the crystallinity of the Co3O4, which indicates the increase in dispersion capacity of Co species on Al2O3. The diffraction signal was observed at 47.5° assigned to the Co-Ce-O phase (JCPDS 04–3282) [28]. However, the same peak is overlapped with ceria peak at 47.4⁰. The intensity of these peak decreased with increasing in calcination temperature. These results indicate that the increasing calcination temperature leads to the increase in Ce, and Co interaction and formation of amorphous or lower crystalline phase of Ce. The interaction also leads to the decrease crystallite size [29]. The increases in calcination temperature was increases the interaction between Co and Ce above the calcination higher than 400 °C [30]. However, slight decrease in intensity of peaks at 600 °C indicate the decrease in crystallinity and the interaction between cobalt and ceria. 3.1.2 Elemental composition (ICP-OES) Elemental composition of synthesized CoAl and CoCe0.1Al catalyst calcined at 500, 550 and 600 °C is shown in the Table 1 . The lower conecntration could be due to the handling loss during preparation. 3.1.3 ATR-FTIR study FTIR spectra of CoCe0.1Al samples calcined at various temperatures (500, 550, and 600 °C) were displayed in Fig. 2 . The CoAl showed vibrations at 657 and 556 cm−1 was assigned to tetrahedral Co2+-O and octahedral Co3+-O stretching vibrations. The presence of these two sharp bands indicates the formation of the Co3O4 spinel structure [31]. The increase in calcination temperature leads to the increment in intensity, which indicates the generation of the Co3O4 phase and strong interaction with Ce. However, at high temperatures (600 °C), the intensity of these bands decreases, which could indicate the lower interaction and dispersion of Co on the Al2O3 support. 3.1.4 Raman analysis The CoCe0.1Al catalysts calcined at 450 to 600 °C were shown in Fig. 3 . Co3O4 Raman showed F2g symmetry modes at 551 and 631 cm−1 as well as Eg and A1g modes at 504 and 715 cm−1 respectively which attributed to the octahedral Co3+. All CoCexAl catalysts showed very weak intense band at 462 cm−1 due to Ce F2g mode of Ce-O stretching frequency [31]. In the CoAl and CoCe0.1Al_500 °C sample, a very low-intensity band observed at 711 cm−1 of A1g mode could be assigned to the CoAl2O4. This band disappeared after calcination at higher temperature (above 500 °C). In addition, the peak at 600 cm−1 originated from the oxygen vacancies from Ce4+ to Ce3+ conversion. The removal of oxygen or electrons in CeO2 causes oxygen vacancies and defects in the lattice, resulting in the formation of lattice strain. The rise in calcination temperature causes these distortions in the lattice structure [32]. Hence, oxygen vacancies are increases slightly with annealing/calcination temperature as more strain occurred in Co and Ce lattice which is also evidenced by XPS quantitatively. The collection of peaks or broad peaks found at 750 to 870 cm−1 can be attributed to Al-OH translation vibrations due to the Al2O3 which is not highly Raman active [33]. Thus, the most active and dominant Co3O4 phase formation was observed which was also evidenced by XRD results. 3.1.5 H2-TPR analysis The H2-reduction curve of CoCe0.1Al synthesized at different calcination temperatures depicted in Fig. 4 . The CoAl displayed two main peaks at 555 and 739 °C due to reduction of Co3+ → Co2+ → Co0 respectively. The TPR peaks above 550 °C) attributed to the Co2+ to metallic Co0. The CoCe0.1Al calcined at 500 °C showed H2 consumption at 388, 520 and 562 °C due to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, Co2+ to Co0 and reduction of Co2+ interacting with CeO2 respectively. The reduction profile at high-temperature (> 700 °C) denotes the elimination of bulk oxygen of CeO2 as well as could be due to ceria-alumina inrerface (CeAl2O3) [34]. The increase in calcination temperature leads to the shifting of reduction towards lower side. These findings suggest that the cobalt ion facilitated the CeO2 reduction. In the case of CoCe0.1Al_550 °C, the reduction peak shifted to lower temperature at 384, 519, 605 and 745 °C. The low-temperature reduction indicate the facile redox behavior of Co and Ce. The H2 consumption is reported in Table 2 . The CoCe0.1Al_550 catalyst showed higher consumption of H2 at low temperature than CoCe0.1Al_500 and CoCe0.1Al_600. The higher H2 consumption could be due to the presence of maximum amount of facile adsorbed oxygen present on the surface of the CoCe0.1Al_550 catalyst. The higher amount of H2 consumption was observed at low temperature by the surface adsorbed oxygen species and Ce species [40]. In addition, the doping of Ce into CoAl leads to the formation of maximum adsorbed as well as lattice oxygen species which facilitate the low temperature CO oxidation activity. Thus, the optimum calcination temperature (550 ⁰C) could enhance the interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2 which improved the redox properties. Furthermore, the reduction profile of CoCe0.1Al_550 shows high oxygen mobility on the reducible support at low temperatures during the reaction. These results indicate the strong synergistic effect can promote the reducibility of Co and surface CeO2 species due to optimum calcination temperature. 3.1.6 XPS The XPS measurement was carried out to identify the surface of the catalyst composition. The cobalt and oxygen distribution were investigated by O 1 s and Co 2p spectra of CoAl, CoCe0.1Al_500, CoCe0.1Al_550, and CoCe0.1Al_600 catalysts and displayed in (Fig. 4. a, b) respectively. The O 1 s spectra consisted of three different characteristic peaks located at 530.2, 531.6, and 532.8 eV are corresponds to lattice oxygen (OL), adsorbed oxygen species like O2 2− and O − (Oa), and surface oxygen species (Os) of hydroxyl groups, respectively [34,35]. The addition of Ce (0.1 mol) results in the remarkable shift in binding energy and enhancement in the oxygen species on the surface of catalyst due to the availability of oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, the increasing calcination temperature of CoCe0.1Al from 500 to 550 °C showed increase in the estimated area of surface adsorbed oxygen species with lowering of binding energy (Table 3 ). However, the existence of a maximum number of oxygen vacancies effectively enhances the ability to activate oxygen and accelerate CO oxidation. The Co 2p XPS spectra of CoAl and CoCe0.1Al was compared in Fig. 4b. The spectrum of Co 2p has shown two main peaks centered at B.E. of 780 and 795 eV for Co (2p3/2) and Co (2p1/2) with two satellite points respectively. The Co 2p3/2 showed two peaks located at lower binding energy 780 and 782 eV, indicates the presence of Co3+and Co2+ in the spinel phase. Moreover, the signal observed at higher binding energy (785 and 802 eV) were assigned to the satellite signals from the Co2+ and Co3+. The CoCe0.1Al calcined at 500, 550, and 600 °C showed enhancement in the intensity of the Co 2p peak. This indicate the increase in amount of active Co sites on the catalyst surface [26]. The peak binding energy shifted to the lower side indicates a significant interaction between CeO2 and Co3O4 as well as increased oxygen availability at the reaction site. The Ce 3d spectra shown eight peaks, each correlating to four sets of spin-orbit doublets. Ce 3d5/2 signal labeled as v and Ce 3d3/2 signal denoted as u. The pairs of (u' and v') are assigned to the 3d104f1 electronic state to Ce3+ ions and (u, u''', v, v''') peaks are highlighted to the 3d104f0 state of Ce4+ species. In addition, the peaks marked as u'' and v'' represent the presence of oxygen vacancies [35]. The Ce 3d5/2 - Ce 3d3/2 spin-orbit splitting was noticed in the range of 880 to 920 eV. There are two main peaks of Ce 3d5/2 observed at 887 eV (u') and 902 eV (v') corresponds to the Ce3+ state and 3d3/2 peaks observed at 881 eV (u), 897 eV (u'''), 900 eV (v), and 915 eV (v''') which attributed to Ce4+species [36]. The increase in calcination temperature from 500 to 550 °C leads to the increase in ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ (0.27 to 0.31) and is associated with enhancement of the quantity of oxygen vacancies (Table 4 ). The increase in Ce3+ concentration on CeO2 surface is related to the generation oxygen vacancies. In addition, high concentration of Ce3+ could be due to the transfer of electrons from cobalt to ceria. Furthermore, the decease in Ce species intensity with increase in calcination temperature could be due to the formation of maximum oxide layer on surface. Furthermore, considerable dispersion of Ce species occurred at high calcination temperatures, resulting in the absence of identifiable peaks in XRD which is inline [37] which is inline with XPS results. The Al 2p XPS profile of CoAl and CoCexAl at around 74.7 to 75.2 eV, and correspond to the Al3+ bonded to oxygen is shown in Fig. 5 c. The bare Al2O3 showed Al 2p signal at 74.7 eV. However, CoCe0.1Al_500, CoCe0.1Al_550, and CoCe0.1Al_600 showed slight increase in binding energy with increase in calcination temperature. This could be due to the well distribution of Ce and Co on the alumina surface. 3.1.7 27Al mas nmr The coordination states of aluminum species in Ce doped CoAl samples calcined at 500, 550 and 600 °C have been investigated by 27Al MAS NMR and shown in Fig. 6 . The most intense peak observed at 13.2 ppm in bare Al2O3 which is typical hexacoordinated Al (AlO6) [38]. Ce doped CoAl (CoCe0.1Al) showed NMR peak at 40 ppm attributed to the pentacoordinated Al species (AlO5) [38]. The CoAl showed low intense peak of Al coordination due to lower crystallinity. The AlO5 aluminum coordination was formed by calcination of oxides at various temperatures and interaction with Co and Ce. The increase in calcination temperature from 500 to 600 °C leads to the gradually increase in formation of the in AlO5 coordination with AlO6. Penta coordinated Al formation occurred at >500 °C and its concentration increases with the calcination temperature [39]. The increase in the ratio of AlO5/AlO6 with increasing in calcination temperature was observed and the order is CoCe0.1Al (0.04) < CoCe0.1Al_550 (0.12) < CoCe0.1Al_600 (0.47). Hence, the performance of CoCe0.1Al_550 catalyst depends on the hexacordinated Al species with optimum AlO5 species. Calcination altered the concentration of hexacoordinated and pentacoordinated Al. In addition, the shifting of 13.2 ppm peak (AlO6) was observed in the CoCe0.1Al_500 (14.1), CoCe0.1Al_550 (11.1) and CoCe0.1Al_600 (13.2) samples. This indicate that the formation of a distorted coordination environment of Al was due to the significant metal-to-metal interaction. Hence, the existence of AlO5 coordination in CoCe0.1Al catalyst resembles formation of the defect and more amount of oxygen vacancies in the adjacent oxygen atom to Al [40]. 3.2 Catalyst activity The catalytic test of Ce added CoAl catalyst calcined at 500, 550, and 600 °C for CO oxidation are presented in Fig. 7 and Table 5 . The Ce doped CoAl system prepared by coprecipitation followed by deposition precipitation method showed low-temperature CO oxidation. CoCe0.1Al calcined at 550 °C showed complete CO conversion at 130 °C (CoCe0.1Al_550). However, the CoCe0.1Al calcined at 500 °C showed 100% CO conversion (T100) at 200 °C due to the presence of minimum amount of active sites. The Co3O4 is active species for CO oxidation via the Co3+/Co2+ redox cycle. Moreover, increase in calcination temperature to 600 °C, increase in the particle size with decrease in surface area was observed. This leads to the shifting of the CO oxidation towards higher temperature compared to the catalyst calcined at 550 ⁰C. The larger surface area of the CoCe0.1Al_550 catalyst could loosen the Co-O bond strength and consequently form the facile lattice oxygen [41]. Therefore, the catalyst showed improvement in redox behavior concluded by H2-TPR. The T100 for CO oxidation was observed and order is CoAl > CoCe0.1Al_500 > COCe0.1Al_600 > CoCe0.1Al_550. The interaction across Co, Ce and Al leads to the formation of the maximum adsorbed oxygen species on catalyst surface with optimum penta and hexa coordinated alumina. The formation of these species resulting in a decline in activation energy for CO oxidation with increase in the rate for CO oxidation was observed. The TPR and XPS results indicate the formation of facile active Co3+ and Ce3+ species with lower binding energy. In addition, the maximum amount of H2 consumption occurred in CoCe0.1Al_550 correlated with the higher amount of adsorbed surface active species available for low temperature CO oxidation. The Ce3+ species showed presence of oxygen vacancies which was responsible for the facile activation of gaseous oxygen [42]. The more facile Co3+ species could easily donate the oxygen repsonsible for the improvement in CO oxidation. The Co3O4 showed higher dispersion on CeO2 with optimum crytallinity and generation more amount of oxygen active species. The strong interaction of cobalt and ceria with alumina active species such as AlO5 and AlO6 stabilizes the size of Co3O4 particles at 550 °C. The catalyst calcined at > 500 °C showed maximum lattice strain in the crystal and generation of defects utimately the amount of oxygen vacancies increses. The catalyst calcined at 500 °C showed formation of pentacoordinated alumina which was increased with calcination temperature. In addition, the increase in calcination temperature to 550 °C leads to the change in the morphology of the support indicated by change in the ratio of AlO5/AlO6. In case of CoCe0.1Al_550 the AlO6 and AlO5 showed optimum 0.12 ratio which resulted in high CO oxidation activity. The presence of maximum oxygen vacancies, optimum crystalline size of Co3O4, maximum adsorbed oxygen species and stronger interaction between Co, Ce and Al2O3 observed in CoCe0.1Al calcined at 550 °C. All these species responsible for the decrease in activation energy and increase in rate of CO conversion at lower temperature. However, increase in calcination temperature leads to the increase in penta coordinated alumina concentration with decresae in surface area, adsorbed oxygen concentration and oxygen vacancies with increase in crystallite size of Co3O4. The high temperature calcination also leads to the increase in activation energy and decrease in conversion rate of CO. Therefore CoCe0.1Al calcined at 600 °C showed CO oxidation at higher temperature. The CoCe0.1Al calcined at 550 °C showed optimum concentration of active species which was responsible for the maximum CO oxidation at lower temperature compared to the CoCe0.1Al calcined at 500 and 600 °C. Reaction conditions – CO:300 ppm, O2:5%), with Helium balance, GHSV:20,000 mL.g−1.h−1 4 Conclusion The calcination temperature has an influence on CO oxidation activity of CoCe0.1Al and has been studied with detailed characterizations. The CoCe0.1Al catalysts calcined at 500, 550, and 600 °C have demonstrated variable catalytic activity. The CoCe0.1Al showed higher CO oxidation at lower temperature (130 °C) after calcination at 550 °C. The increase in activity attributed to the presence of more facile Co3+, Ce3 and adsorbed oxygen species. The interaction of these species with alumina forms optimum concentration of penta and hexa-coordinated alumina in the catalyst. However, increase in calcination temperature leads to the formation of higher crystallite size, higher penta coordinated alumina and lower adsorbed oxygen. This leads to the shifting of the CO oxidation activity at higher temperature. coredata.dc:description: The low-temperature behavior of CO oxidation was investigated using 0.1 mol Ce doped Co supported on alumina catalysts prepared using co-precipitation followed by deposition precipitation method. The impact of calcination temperature on CO oxidation with kinetic aspects has been studied in detail and correlated to the characterizations. The Ce doped CoAl catalyst calcined at optimum temperature (550 ⁰C) shoed formation of more facile Co3+, Ce3+, and adsorbed species. The Co, Ce, and alumina interaction leads to the formation of optimum penta and hexa coordinated alumina. The physicochemical properties of the catalyst have been studied in detail using XRD, FTIR, Raman, TPR, XPS, and 27Al NMR and correlated to the catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Co supported on Cex[Al2O3]0.5-x as an effective catalyst for low-temperature CO oxidation: Effect of calcination temperature
